If a circular body TCB roll down an inclined plane by unfolding a thread, or by friction which prevents all Aiding, the ſpace deſeribed will be to that which the body would deſcribe freely as CG to CO ; for the tendency down the inclined plane is a determined proportion of the weight of the body. The motion of rotation in theſe caſes, both progreſſive and whirling, is uniformly accelerated.

Something of the ſame kind obtains in common pendulous bodies. A ball hung by a thread not only oſcillates, but alſo makes part of a rotation ; and for this reaſon its oſcillations differ from thoſe of a heavy point hanging by the ſame thread, and the centre of oſcillation is a little below the centre of the ball. A ball hung by a thread, and oſeillating between cycloidal cheeks, does not ofcillate like a body in a cycloid, becauſe its centre of oſcillation is continually ſhiſting its place. Huyghens avoided this by ſuſpending his pendulous body from two points, ſo that it did not change its attitude during its oſcillation. If ourſpring-carriages wrere hung in this manner, having the four lower ſtaples to wſhich the ſtraps are fixed as far aſun-rier as the four upper ſtaples at the ends of the ſprings, the body of the carriage would perform its oſcillations without kicking up and down in the diſagreeable manner they now do, by which we are frequently in danger oſ ſtriking the glaſſes with our heads. The ſwings would indeed be greater, but incomparably eaſeer; and we could hold things almoſt as ſteadily in our hand as if the carriage were not fwinging at all.
This will ſuſſice for an account of the rotation round fixed axes, as the foundation for a theory of machines actually performing work. The limits oſ our under

Let there be any machine of the rotatory kind, i. e. compoſed of levers or wheels, and let its conſtruction be ſuch, that the velocity of the point to wſhich the power is applied (which we ſhall call the impelled point) is to the velocity of the working point in the ratio of vι to n. It is well known that the energy of this machine will be the ſame with that of an axis in peritrochio, of which the radii are m and n.

Let χ be the inertia of the power, or the quantity of dead matter which muſt move with the velocity of the impelled point in order that the moving power may act. Thus the moving power may be the weight of a bucket of water in a water-wheel ; then x is the quantity of matter in this bucket of water. We ſhall give a very ſimple example of the utility of theſe formulæ. Let us ſuppoſe that water is to be raiſed in a bucket by the deſeent of a weight, and that the machine is a ſimple pulley. Such a machine is deſeribed by Deſaguliers *, who ſays he found it preferable to all other machines. The bucket dipped itſelf in the ciſtern.
